title: Gold price tumbles after Trump names pick to lead US Federal Reserve
text:
The slide in the price of gold bullion has continued, with the rare metal fetching $US4738 an ounce at 10.30am AEDT, a drop of 2.5 per cent.

Late week's rally ran out of steam after US President Donald Trump picked Kevin Warsh to become the new Federal Reserve chair.

Gold reached about $US5600 during last Thursday after climbing to a then-record $US5000 on Monday.

The price of gold bullion has fallen since last week's record jump.. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

Capital.com senior market analyst Kyle Rodda told The Australian Financial Review today the sell-off was the biggest since the 1920s.

"Ultimately, the markets have welcomed the Warsh nomination. He's seen as experienced, competent and representing a respect by the Trump administration of merit and aptitude over loyalty and servility," Rodda said.

"The apparent respect for institutional integrity from the Trump administration helped spark a recovery in the US dollar and the collapse in precious metals on the basis that the central bank will be guided by a credible person."

Warsh could bring about sweeping changes at a central bank that dominates the global economy and markets like no other.

He would replace current Fed Reserve chair Jerome Powell when his term expires in May.

Trump chose Powell to lead the Fed in 2017 but this year has relentlessly assailed him for not cutting interest rates quickly enough.

The retreat from gold has also spurred falls in the prices of other precious metals.

Silver has crashed by more than 36 per cent from its peak last week.﻿

title: 'Confusion, anxiety': Expats from one country urged to check citizenship status
text:
An "unconstitutional"﻿ law that stripped citizenship from South African dual nationals has been reversed – and the implications have sent a ripple of confusion and alarm throughout the expat community.

The South African Citizenship Act (Act 88 of 1995) previously required South Africans to seek ministerial permission to retain their citizenship before becoming citizens of another country, including Australia.

Anyone who failed to do so would lose their citizenship – until now.

South Africans who became citizens of another country without ministerial permission after 1995 automatically lost their SA citizenship. (Getty)

Citizenship restoration is now in full swing after a court ruled this provision was unconstitutional and invalid in May 2025.

It is not automatic and eligible expats need to use the reinstatement portal.

It only applies to those who have lost their citizenship on or after 6 October 1995, according to the South African High Commission.

There were 214,790 South African-born people living in Australia as of 2023, according to the Australian Department of Home Affairs.

READ MORE: Residents in fear after teenagers invited to planned mass bike rideout in Sydney

What is the dual citizenship law in South Africa?

Reinstated citizens – including those who retained their citizenship prior to the rule change – are required to enter and exit South Africa using a South African passport﻿, a rule similar to the ETA scheme soon coming into effect in Britain.

This has been the entry and exit requirement in South Africa since 2004.﻿

It may impact thousands﻿ of Australian-South African dual citizens who wish to resume their citizenship after their SA passports expired.

The Australian government's Smartraveller advice﻿ states that "if you hold Australian-South African dual nationality, by law you must enter and exit on your South African passport".

"We recommend all possible dual nationals consult the South African Department of Home Affairs website to verify your citizenship status," Smartraveller noted.

The SA High Commission also states the same on its website.﻿

Most other visitors, including those from Australia, the US, UK, Canada and New Zealand, don't need a visa for tourist or business stays under 90 days.

Hayley Reichert, a South African-born expat and advocate living in London, initiated the "Loss of Citizenship Campaign" in 2014, which eventually led to last year's court ruling.

Reichert told nine.com.au there is now "significant confusion" around South African expats hoping to return home on foreign passports after the resumption of their citizenship.

Hayley Reichert is a passionate advocate for South Africans living abroad. (Supplied)

She runs a voluntary initiative supporting South Africans abroad named Operation Watershed and has been working to help expats with this constitutional change.

"Many now fear the issuance of fines, detention, refusal of travel, and even the threat of imprisonment," Reichert said.

"This climate of anxiety is disproportionate to the actual legal and practical reality."

What happens if my South African passport has expired?

The law states that citizens must have a valid South African passport or proof of renunciation of citizenship to enter or exit.

However, Reichert has called for calm among expats.

She said South African border control has a "degree of institutional understanding" over the challenges now faced by dual nationals.

﻿There may not be blanket punitive enforcement of this rule, she explained.

"In theory, repeat non-compliance can result in fines or prosecution (up to 12 months' imprisonment), but in practice this is extremely rare," Reichert said.

"Most individuals resolve their documentation after a first warning."

The Embassy of the Republic of South Africa said the department acknowledges that many dual citizens may not be aware of the amendment to the act and the implications for their travel.

"We have therefore decided that affected South Africans departing or arriving through our ports of entry, attempting to use a foreign passport, will be issued with a warning giving them three months to obtain a South African passport," it stated in a notice.

"They will be allowed to depart or enter South Africa."

You don't need a visa if you're visiting South Africa for tourism purposes for up to 90 days. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

"In many cases, travellers receive a formal warning and stamp in their foreign passport noting that South African citizens are not permitted to enter or exit on foreign passports and are instructed to regularise their South African documents," Reichert added.

Reichert encouraged South Africans living abroad﻿ to do their research and contact the relevant authorities before booking or cancelling trips over this entry requirement.

She said dual citizens had a responsibility to comply with the law ﻿– but called for calm amid "confusion, anxiety and misinformation".

Can Australian-born children get South African citizenship?

The SA High Commission states that a child born outside of South Africa to at least one parent with South African citizenship has a claim to citizenship by descent.

They must register the birth in South Africa to obtain citizenship.

title: Caitlan was homeless at 11. School was both a safe haven and a source of humiliation
text:
Caitlan was just 11 years old and in her last year of primary school when she became homeless.

It is almost impossible to comprehend, especially in a country like Australia — a child, homeless and preparing to begin high school.

"After losing my home, school was something that was like a stable place for me and a constant," the now 18-year-old said.

"That was really all I had."

The safety that school provided Caitlan soon disappeared, drowned out by the stress associated with not having access to basic amenities most take for granted.

Child poverty hits WA high Rates of child poverty in WA have doubled in a decade, but there is a severe lack of crisis accommodation, prompting experts to call on governments to do more.

"I would beg to sleep on friends' couches and try to keep myself invisible and not draw any attention to myself," Caitlan said.

"I was ashamed.

"Even there [school] as my only place of stability and the only place where I felt like I was safe or I belonged … I still didn't feel safe to tell anybody what was happening to me."

More young people need help

According to the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, on any given day in 2025, 11,900 unaccompanied children and young people (between the age of 12-24) were assisted by specialist homelessness services across Australia.

WA has the highest number of people turned away from homelessness services in the country. (AAP Image: Dave Hunt)

In Western Australia, 830 children and young people receive support on any given day — a 17 per cent increase from the year before.

WA also has the highest number of people turned away from homelessness services in the country, with an average of 96 requests for assistance unable to be met on a daily basis.

Homeless battle poor sleep, bad diets and stress Western Australian research is showing a strong link between homelessness and poor health, with life expectancy more than 30 years lower for people without secure housing.

For Caitlan, who has just finished her final year of high school and is a member of WA's Youth Homelessness Advisory Council, knowing there are hundreds of children and young people experiencing homelessness and trying to keep up with school is devastating.

"I experienced homelessness in Melbourne for four years, three of which I did not attend school," she said.

"I was very lucky that I was able to get support and stable housing [with family in WA].

"There are still so many young people out there experiencing what I had to experience … and there isn't that support accessible to them.

"Seeing the numbers and seeing the reality of the crisis here in WA is not shocking because I know that there are gaps in the system that need to be fixed."

Coalition calls for action

A coalition of peak bodies, frontline services and young people is hoping to persuade the WA government to prioritise ending youth homelessness, calling for $150 million to be spent on the issue in the upcoming WA state budget.

Youth Affairs Council of WA CEO Kylie Wallace is calling for more action to address youth homelessness. (ABC News: Briana Shepherd )

"We shouldn't have a huge hidden population of hundreds of school students experiencing rough sleeping and homelessness in the wealthiest state in Australia," Youth Affairs Council of WA CEO Kylie Wallace said.

"For every crisis bed that becomes available each night [in Perth], 69 children and young people are competing for that one bed.

"Housing stability is foundational to education, wellbeing and future opportunity.

"[We're] calling on the state government to acknowledge this is a crisis and respond via a targeted investment in the upcoming state budget."

Kylie Wallace and Caitlin want the government to prioritise ending youth homelessness. (ABC News: Briana Shepherd )

While Ms Wallace acknowledged the state government had boosted funding towards homelessness services, including a record investment into new social housing, she said there had been little investment directly targeted towards children and young people.

"We shouldn't have a huge hidden population of hundreds of school students experiencing rough sleeping and homelessness in the wealthiest state in Australia," she said.

"Commitments made in the next state budget could solve it."

Government backs strategy

WA's Minister for Homelessness Matthew Swinbourn said the state government had supported homelessness services like no other government had.

"We don't accept young people not being able to get a home or to be facing homelessness," he said.

"We're in the middle of the 10-year homelessness strategy and very soon I'll be releasing the next five-year action plan inside of that.

Matthew Swinbourn says the state government is committed to supporting homelessness services. (ABC News: Keane Bourke)

"What we find when young people experience homelessness, if we are able to get the supports around them, then typically they don't necessarily experience homelessness in later life."

That was a sentiment the government and those working in the sector agreed on.

"If we don't do this, WA's youth homelessness crisis will deepen," Ms Wallace said.

title: Bree Walker wants the pressure of competing for Olympic gold
text:
The g-force felt hurtling down the bobsleigh track is the only pressure Bree Walker is feeling despite the Australian speed demon entering the Winter Olympics as one of the gold-medal favourites.

Sliders in the newly-rebuilt Cortina d'Ampezzo circuit will hit speeds of 125 kilometres per hour, often reaching five gs — which is similar to a F1 driver or a fighter jet pilot.

Ranked number two after three wins this season among five podium finishes from seven world cup starts, Walker could not be better placed to claim a historic Olympic monobob medal for Australia at the 2026 Games.

Loading Instagram content

Rather than feel burdened by expectation, the 33-year-old told AAP she was embracing it.

"I don't feel pressure in a negative way at all — it's what I wanted," Walker, who finished fifth in the inaugural monobob event held at the Beijing Games in 2022, said.

"I wanted to become one of the best in the world, I wanted to be winning medals for Australia and what comes with that is, obviously, the pressure to compete against the best.

"And so I use that energy to put towards my racing because I get excited by that — I get excited by tight races, by competing with the best and striving for medals.

"So, no, it's not a negative thing at all — I use that as positive energy and I put it towards my races because, really I'm just a true racer at heart."

Aussie Olympic preparations continue after COVID-19 positive tests Australia's Winter Olympics preparations will continue with minimal fuss in northern Italy despite two members of staff testing positive for COVID-19.

A former track athlete who transitioned to bobsleigh 10 years ago, Walker says she is so competitive it is almost embarrassing.

"I'm competitive in everything that I do, whether it's a card game with the team at night — I'm really bad at snap — it's the worst and I'm highly embarrassed by that," said the Melbourne-raised, Cairns-based star.

"But it's what sets my soul on fire … I love bobsleigh because of the speed, because I've always loved just going fast.

"I love races where I'm out in front and people are hunting me down, I love chasing people.

"That's what I'm really looking forward to at these Games, and it's what I've loved throughout this whole season."

Bree Walker (left) and Kiara Reddingius will team up in the two-woman bobsleigh event. (Getty Images: AOC/Marco M. Mantovani)

The Eugenio Monti Sliding Centre opened last March and has 16 curves over a distance of 1,749 metres.

Walker finished third at the Olympic test event late last year and said it suited her strengths, which included her explosive power starts.

"I really love the track, it's a bobsleigh pilot's dream," Walker said.

"You have to be really fast at the start because it's a very steep start ramp but the top section of the track is where you build a lot of your speed.

"There's lots of twists and turns, so as a pilot, you really have to get to work in order to be able to execute those corners and then as you're going down the track, it gets flowier and faster, and that's when you can really let the sled fly."

Walker will also team up with Kiara Reddingius, who grew up in Kalgoorlie, with the pair looking to improve on their 16th-placed finish in the two-woman bobsleigh in Beijing.

The women's monobob will begin on February 15 at 8pm, AEDT, with the medal round held on February 17 from 7am.

AAP

title: An old man and animals in the zoo — the best quotes from the Australian Open
text:
The 2026 Australian Open has provided some remarkable tennis across the board, but it has also seen some memorable quotes — both good and bad.

Despite world number one and this year's runner-up Aryna Sabalenka saying "I don't want to talk about tennis", we do, so here are some of the best quotes of the tournament.

'Animals in the zoo?'

American star Coco Gauff suggested players do not have enough privacy at the AO after vision of her smashing a racquet was broadcast on television.

Gauff had just lost her quarterfinal in straight sets to Ukraine's Elina Svitolina and journeyed down the tunnels to smash her racquet away from cameras, or so she thought.

Coco Gauff smashes her racquet after losing an Australian Open quarterfinal. (Supplied: Channel 9)

"I tried to go somewhere where they wouldn't broadcast it, but obviously they did," she said.

"Maybe some conversations can be had because I feel like at this tournament, the only private place we have is the locker room."

Other players came out in support of Gauff's sentiments, including Iga Świątek.

"The question is, are we tennis players or are we animals in the zoo, where they are observed even when they poop?" Swiatek said.

"It's not our job [to] be a meme when you forget your accreditation. Oh, it's funny, for sure. People have something to talk about, but for us I don't think it's necessary."

Novak Djokovic added to the debate, saying, "I'm surprised that we have no cameras while we are taking a shower. That's probably the next step."

'Old man' wants a cut of ticket sales

While we're talking about Djokovic, remember what he said after his insane five-set win over defending champion Jannik Sinner in the semifinal?

"I'm an old man, I need to go earlier to sleep," he said after the semifinal ended way past his self-prescribed bedtime.

Djokovic also made a cheeky joke that he wanted "10 per cent of tonight's tickets sold" because of the entertaining match he and Sinner put on. We're not sure that's how it works, though.

Novak Djokovic played in his 11th Australian Open title. (Getty Images: Darrian Traynor)

After the other semifinal between Alexander Zverev and Carlos Alcaraz, the German said he wasn't a fan of how the Spaniard utilised murky medical timeout rules.

"I didn't like it, but it's not my decision. I just said it was bulls***, basically," he said.

Alcaraz was allowed a medical timeout late in the third set of the intense match for what he said was an adductor issue, but what many believe looked more like cramp.

He said the injury was very painful but it wasn't going to force him to retire because he "hates giving up".

"I always say you have to believe in yourself no matter what," Alcaraz said. That's a nice motivational quote!

Legends say thanks

Stan Wawrinka has long been a favourite here at Melbourne Park, probably even before his breakthrough grand slam title at the 2014 Australian Open.

But he bid farewell to the slam after losing to ninth seed Taylor Fritz in the third round.

Wawrinka fought back tears as he sat on his bench after the match, before joining tournament director Craig Tiley on the court to thank an adoring crowd and sign off his Open career in the most Australian way possible.

"First of all, thank you to Craig for the wildcard invitation, not the first time," he said.

"For me it was a lot of emotion when you called me to give me this opportunity for one last chance to say goodbye to the people here in Melbourne.

"I'm sad to leave, but it's been an amazing journey."

To sign off for good, he grabbed two beers from his bag, gave one to Tiley and cracked the other himself.

"Cheers everybody, and thank you so much."

The 2026 Open even marked a goodbye for Frenchman Gael Monfils, who lost in the first round to Aussie Dane Sweeny.

"For me, my journey here with you guys started in 2003, when I came here for the first time," Monfils said.

"Now we are in 2026 and somehow it is the finish line but thank you so much for this amazing ride."

Monfils has played his last Australian Open. (Getty: Morgan Hancock)

De Minaur's wedding confession

The trouble with being part of a tennis power couple is keeping the personal and professional separate, as Alex de Minaur found out after his win over America's Frances Tiafoe during the third round.

A relieved de Minaur spoke to Jim Courier on court post-match, and after taking a few questions about his win and his opponent, talk soon turned to planning for his wedding to English tennis player Katie Boulter, which will take place this year.

"This is a 50-50 relationship, so honestly the fact that we're both tennis players [means] we are both doing as much as we can together," he said.

"And yeah, I've been involved so far with some of the decisions.

" I'm sure when it comes to like, the details of napkins and flowers and, you know, decoration purposes, that's not my forte. I'll leave that to Katie. "

Cue a puzzled face from Boulter in the crowd …

Osaka feels like a Barbie

"I almost feel like I'm a Barbie that dresses up and goes on the court and does something," Naomi Osaka said following her fashion statement at the tournament.

Ahead of facing Antonia Ružić in the first round, Osaka wore a white hat and veil, matched by flowing pants and an umbrella in the same colour.

"It's modelled after a jellyfish. I am so grateful to be able to get to do the things I love," she said.

"It's really beautiful."

Naomi Osaka got the crowd talking with her outfit. (Getty Images: Quinn Rooney)

Honourable mentions

The best of the rest starts with the statistical best men's player of all time reminding people of just that.

After his quarterfinal win, Djokovic said he found it "disrespectful" that he was asked if he felt like he has always been the chaser, chasing Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal to Jannik Sinner and Carlos Alcaraz.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

"There's probably about a 15-year period in between where I was dominating the grand slams," he said.

"I don't feel like I'm chasing, to be honest."

Canada's Felix Auger-Aliassime said he was sick of feeling "like a punching bag" in reference to his recent torrid injury record.

Australia's Taylah Preston said she felt it wouldn't be long until we had a local winner at the Open.

"I think there's a lot of us that are really pushing and getting super close at having really good results at these tournaments," she said.

Thanasi Kokkinakis admitted after he and Nick Kyrgios lost their men's doubles first-round match that the crowd "saw probably a couple of shadows of our former selves".

Kyrgios made an error when he said he and Kokkinakis were playing for "millions of dollars". (AAP: Joel Carrett)

Kyrgios was more focused on a controversial decision in that match, though.

"It doesn't make any f***ing sense. I'm pissed off," he said.

"We're playing for millions of dollars, we've been both injured, both trying to get to this stage, and then some of these rules are just so, so, so dumb."

The men's doubles prize money is in fact $900,000, not quite millions, but we take your point, Nick.

title: Grammys 2026 live: Hottest 100 winner Olivia Dean wins Best New Artist
text:
The music world's biggest award ceremony, the Grammys, is taking place in Los Angeles today, hosted by Trevor Noah for the sixth time running.

Australia's Tame Impala has already secured a golden gramophone for Best Dance/Electronica Recording at the Grammy Awards Premiere Ceremony.

title: What are the chances the RBA will raise interest rates?
text:
The market thinks the likelihood of the RBA lifting interest rates tomorrow is 72 per cent.

But here's a very important caveat — the market has been wrong before and at some point it will be wrong again.

You don't even have to look very far back to find a glaring example.

In July last year, the market was 96 per cent confident the RBA was about to cut rates. It was wrong.

Independent economist Nicki Hutley says the market's predictions are normally pretty good but forecasting is harder when the data on inflation is less clear.

"I think the market has overreacted to the December inflation data," she said. "There is something that we need to be watching closely but it feels like it's a bit of a 'henny penny, the sky is falling' over-reaction to me."

What do economists predict?

We consulted five leading economists. Here's what they think in a nutshell:

Nicki Hutley: Rate rise

Richard Holden: Rate rise

Cassandra Winzar: Rate rise

Besa Deda: Rate rise

Robert Brooks: On the fence

Ms Hutley says the central bank will be feeling cautious about data showing inflation has ticked up.

"Their language has been quite hawkish in more recent months, and I think they'll feel that a precautionary tiny tweak is worthwhile," she said.

"I don't necessarily think it's the start of a longer cycle of tightening though."

Monash University economist Robert Brooks is less definitive.

"There is sort of a post-pandemic concern that perhaps central banks waited a bit too long to move rates up and therefore let a bit more inflation get into the system," he said.

"But there is a question around timing and that timing has got a balance. So at one level, if rates increased, I don't think that would be a surprise.

"If rates stayed on hold, that wouldn't be a surprise either. I think you could make that case."

But Cassandra Winzar, chief economist at the Committee for Economic Development of Australia, says the argument for an increase is stronger than the case for keeping rates steady.

"[The RBA has] had quite a few months now of inflation being that bit higher than we'd like. So it's not just a one-off," she said.

"There's a fairly strong case that now is the time to take a bit more action and get inflation under control sooner rather than later."

Why would the RBA increase interest rates?

Ms Hutley says the case for a rate rise is due to inflation creeping above the Reserve Bank of Australia's target, which is between 2 per cent and 3 per cent.

"It's not out of hand, but it's certainly not heading in the right direction at the moment," she said. "They are very concerned to make sure that inflation is heading back towards the centre of the target band, not away from it."

University of New South Wales economist Richard Holden says an increase in "trimmed mean" inflation will be of particular concern.

It rose in December to 3.3 per cent from 3.2 per cent in November.

"[That] is a sort of measure of underlying inflation to which the RBA pays attention, it has ticked up," he said. "That's the most compelling argument [for a rate rise]."

Ms Winzar says the fact that unemployment has remained low at 4.1 per cent will also give the RBA confidence to raise the cash rate.

"That gives the RBA little bit more leeway to raise interest rates to try and bring inflation back down into the [target] range without having too much of an effect on labour markets," she said.

Why would the RBA keep interest rates on hold?

Professor Brooks says low unemployment and moderate wage growth mean it would be safe for the RBA to keep rates where they are.

He says the RBA has in the past been concerned that high inflation could feed wage increases, which would then see a rise in prices.

"So that concern of a wage price interaction hasn't manifested itself," he said.

"The second reason why I think you could make a case potentially for rates staying on hold is that even in the face of recent data, inflation expectations have remained stable."

Besa Deda, chief economist at William Buck, says the RBA will also be looking at the resilience of the global economy over the year, despite increasing uncertainty.

She says those risks have seen a sell-off of the US dollar, and a rise in the value of the Australian dollar.

"[It is] higher including in trade-weighted terms, which is the value of our currency against the currencies of the countries that we trade with the most," she said.

"That will help tradables inflation be restrained."

Professor Holden is less convinced, saying there are not many compelling arguments to hold rates.

But he says there is a chance the RBA may want to see more data before making the call to raise.

"You don't just sort of put rates up and down like yo-yos," he said.

"That would be the best argument I think one could muster, which is, maybe it's an anomaly, wait and see.

"But I don't think it's a very persuasive argument."

How high are interest rates anyway?

The Reserve Bank of Australia's official cash rate is 3.6 per cent.

Banks use the cash rate to set their interest rates — new home loan borrowers will currently pay about 5.5 per cent.

What should I read next?

title: Aussie Olympic preparations continue after COVID-19 positive tests
text:
Australia's Winter Olympics preparations will continue with minimal fuss in northern Italy despite two members of staff testing positive for COVID-19.

The team, building towards of the Milano Cortina Games which begins this week, received the news at the Australian Institute of Sport's European Training Centre (ETC) in Gavirate, about an hour's drive from Milan, on Sunday.

The individuals, who will not be competing at the 25th edition of the Olympic Winter Games, were symptomatic and tested positive on January 28 and 31, with measures in place to contain any possible spread of infection.

"The Australian Winter Olympic team has medical protocols in place for any infectious disease or illness and are standard operating procedures for high-performance environments which are being followed," chef de mission and former aerial skier Alisa Camplin said.

"Such protocols have been in place for past Olympics, including the Beijing 2022 Olympic Winter Games and Paris 2024 Olympic Games.

"Alternative plans have been put into place for those scheduled to arrive into the ETC over the next 48 hours."

Close contacts of the two positive cases were immediately tested. They returned negative results and were administered anti-virals.

Fifty-three men and women will compete in green and gold, the second-largest Australian team ever and the largest for 12 years.

AAP

title: Matildas trio help Arsenal to become first-ever club world champions
text:
Arsenal have become the first women's world soccer champions, with Matildas star Caitlin Foord clinching the title for the Gunners in extra time.

Foord scored the Gunners' third in a dramatic 3-2 win over Brazil's Corinthians to seal the FIFA Women's Champions Cup final.

Fellow Matildas Steph Catley and Kyra Cooney-Cross were also celebrating as Arsenal lifted the trophy at their own Emirates Stadium in north London.

The three become the first Australian women to be crowned soccer world champions.

While Foord played her starring role off the bench, Catley played the full 120 minutes of a gripping final in which the South American champions twice levelled, with the second equaliser coming from a last-gasp penalty to force extra time.

Cooney-Cross, still returning to full fitness after a period of compassionate leave in Australia to be with her cancer-stricken mother, was an unused substitute.

She did play in Arsenal's successful UEFA Champions League campaign, which earned them their place in this competition.

Arsenal, who beat African champions AS FAR, the team of the Moroccan military, 6-0 in Wednesday's semi-final, controlled possession for much of the match.

But Corinthians, who beat US champs FC Gotham in their semi, were always a threat, roared on by a large contingent of fans who brought the passion of Sao Paulo to the English capital.

Arsenal opened the scoring after 14 minutes through Canadian striker Olivia Smith, who followed up after Lele had saved a Stina Blackstenius shot.

But seven minutes later Corinthians stunned their hosts. After Duda Sampaio had a drive tipped over the bar 40-year-old veteran Gabi Zanotti headed in from the resultant corner, skimming in off an unfortunate Catley.

As Arsenal pressed, Lele made a string of saves but was finally beaten by Lotte Wubben-Moy's 59th-minute header.

Foord thought she had settled the final with a goal-bound 75th-minute shot, but a defender's desperate lunge turned it against the bar.

Instead, Vic Albuquerque scored a last-gasp penalty awarded on a VAR review to force extra time.

But Foord would not be denied her moment. Late in the first period of extra time, Frida Maanum stole midfield possession and Arsenal broke. Foord stayed onside, received the Norwegian's pass, and drove her shot inside Lele's near post.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

The only previous Australian to attain soccer world champion status is Mark Bosnich, who kept goal for Manchester United when they won the Intercontinental Cup, an annual competition between the European and South American champions, in 1999.

However, that event was not recognised by FIFA at the time and only featured clubs from two continents. In 2016, the world governing body retrospectively designated the winners as world champions.

The new competition features the six continental champions and will run annually, except in years involving the quadrennial 16-club Women's Club World Cup, which is due to launch in 2028.

Australian champions Melbourne City, who were a penalty shoot-out loss from qualifying for this event via last year's Asian Champions League, are at the quarterfinal stage of this season's ACL.

AAP

title: Small towns fight to keep their schools open amid low enrolments
text:
When Ellie Egan heard her daughter's primary school was set to be temporarily closed due to low student numbers, she decided to take matters into her own hands.

She worked with other parents to find families interested in enrolling in Penrose Public School in the New South Wales Southern Highlands.

Ellie Egan says her young daughter is terrified by the prospect of having to go to another school in the next town. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

Despite their efforts, the NSW Department of Education confirmed the school would be put into "recess", with less than three months' notice.

"My daughter still asks me almost daily why her school is closing," Ms Egan said.

" She says if they knew how much she loves her school, they never would've done this. "

Parents fight shutdown

The Education Department can decide to place a school in recess when there are "questions about the school's ongoing viability", according to department protocols.

A school in recess does not enrol students, and staff and equipment are redeployed to nearby schools on an as-needs basis.

Penrose is one of five regional public schools across NSW mothballed from the end of 2025 due to low enrolment numbers.

Kids in Penrose love their little school. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

The school was expecting five students in 2026.

But parents argued their school's dip in enrolments was temporary and that the decision to put it in recess was premature.

"We managed to get a number of new families interested in coming to the school, but ultimately, it counted for nothing because the department didn't listen to us," Ms Egan said.

" We think it was basically just lip service, rather than a true consultation. "

Ms Egan, on behalf of the school parents and citizens association (P&C), submitted a 25-page objection to the Department of Education.

The submission pointed to the department's own data, which showed Penrose could reach 16 enrolments by 2031.

The P&C canvassed the community for potential enrolments and claimed the figure could be higher.

Concerns from the Penrose community have since been escalated to both the NSW Ombudsman and the Secretary of the Department of Education, Murat Dizdar.

The Department of Education declined the ABC's request for an interview.

Capertee was one of five small regional schools put into recess at the end of 2025. (ABC Western Plains: Jonathan Hawes)

Consultation 'didn't happen'

Schools in Ben Lomond, Black Springs, Goolma and Capertee will also be shut down this year.

It brings the number of schools in recess across the state to 19.

Schools in recess are reviewed by the department at least every two years, with sites maintained so they can be reopened if viable, or repurposed if not.

When Shane Adams moved his family to the rural locality of Capertee, the public school was a major drawcard.

"We chose to live here because of the school. We need to think of our kids and their future," he said.

For spread-out farming and mining communities such as Capertee, having a centrally located school is seen as essential for growth. (ABC Western Plains: Jonathan Hawes)

Across the five schools placed into recess at the end of 2025, consultation periods ranged from as little as one month to about eight months.

In 2015, a parliamentary inquiry into NSW public school closures found a "strong pattern" of heavy-handed decision-making that lacked genuine community consultation, particularly in rural and primary school settings.

More than a decade on, parents said little had changed.

"The school my kids will have to go to is 4 kilometres further away, and towards nothing. This one was on my wife's way to work," Mr Adams said.

" The community consultation wasn't just lacking — it didn't happen at all. "

Is 'recess' different from 'closure'?

Under the 1990 Education Act, the NSW education minister must formally propose any school closure by June 15 each year, with schools forbidden from closing until the end of the following year.

This means there is at least an 18-month period to potentially reverse course on a closure.

But the legislation does not mention schools being placed in recess.

Graeme Pike and Shane Adams say the department's consultation should include the broader community. (ABC Western Plains: Jonathan Hawes)

That decision is instead guided by the department's in-house procedures and guidelines, which do not set timeframes for consultation.

The guidelines list key stakeholders to be consulted, including school staff, the P&C, a NSW Teachers Federation organiser and the local MP.

Capertee and District Progress Association president Graeme Pike argued that list was too narrow.

"If the Department of Education had chosen to consult with us, like they should've, then we would've told them how necessary the school is to the growth of the community," Mr Pike said.

" They consulted with people in Bathurst and Orange, but not with people just down the road. "

The department said recess was preferable to closure, as the two-year review period allowed more time for enrolments to recover, compared to the 18-month process for closures mandated by the Education Act.

In the past decade, only one school has reopened after a period of recess — Premer Public School in the Liverpool Plains.

For former Goolma Public School bus driver Jean Ellis, that record offered little reassurance.

Jean Ellis says she is still coming to terms with the idea that Goolma Public School will not open this year. (ABC Western Plains: Jonathan Hawes)

She said she worried losing the school, however temporary, would be another nail in the Central Western community's coffin.

"When we first came here, there were multiple sports organisations, two churches, a shop, the pub, a fire shed, a village hall and the school. [Goolma] was thriving," she said.

"In recent years, the school became the only place left that was open and available to everyone.

"It was the only place to make community."

title: Premiership-winning player sues AFL over 'catastrophic' concussion
text:
A former Northern Territory Football League premiership player is suing his club, the league and the AFL for negligence after suffering "catastrophic injuries" in a head clash with another player in 2022.

Former Nightcliff Tigers forward Trent Melville says the concussion left him suicidal and suffering from chronic headaches, "post-concussion syndrome", hearing loss, pain, insomnia and memory loss, among a list of other symptoms.

In documents filed with the NT Supreme Court, the now 33-year-old dual-premiership player and Chaney Medal winner says he suffered up to seven concussions "and numerous sub-concussive blows to the head" during his football career.

As a result, Mr Melville says he "suffered ongoing memory problems from about 2017" and "was susceptible to serious injury from a further significant blow to the head".

Trent Melville won his second NTFL premiership with the Nightcliff Tigers in 2021. (ABC News: Amy Culpitt)

During a match on October 15, 2022, the documents state Mr Melville "suffered a head clash with another player whilst going for the ball and was concussed resulting in catastrophic injuries".

Mr Melville claims he would not have suffered the injuries if Nightcliff FC, AFLNT and the AFL had kept records of his previous concussions and "warned him that he risked catastrophic injury from a further head knock and prevented him from playing whilst experiencing memory loss".

Mr Melville says the AFL owed him a duty of care to ensure his safety, including by passing on information to leagues and clubs about head injuries and warning players "of the dangers associated with repetitive head injuries".

Mr Melville claims AFLNT in turn should have passed that information on to NTFL clubs and players, while Nightcliff FC should have then passed it on to Tigers players while keeping records of injuries sustained on the field.

AFLNT declined to comment while the case remains before the Supreme Court. (ABC News: Che Chorley)

The documents state all three defendants should also have prevented players "who had ongoing symptoms from previous concussions (such as memory loss) from playing".

"By reason of the breach of duty and/or negligence by the first, second and third defendants, the plaintiff has suffered injury, loss and damage," the documents read.

The Nightcliff Football Club, the NTFL and the AFL are each yet to file a defence with the court.

Mr Melville is seeking damages, interest and costs, with the case due to return to court for a directions hearing in Darwin on March 18.

title: The 'apocalyptic Christian cult' attempting to convert pastors
text:
A South Korean fringe religious organisation, accused of brainwashing members, is targeting pastors in order to recruit entire Australian congregations, a former member says.

Shincheonji, which has been described as an "apocalyptic Christian cult" whose members will be saved from an imminent apocalypse, featured prominently in the Victorian parliamentary inquiry into cults and fringe groups.

The ABC has previously reported that the church is using "special force teams" and aggressive tactics to expand its recruitment outside of Melbourne in an effort to grow its flock.

Matthew, whose name has been changed to protect his identity, spent nearly five years inside Shincheonji, and said the organisation was also targeting the pastors of other churches in an effort to recruit entire existing congregations through a "Pastor Evangelism Team".

Matthew was a member of that team until he left the church last year.

"Our goal was to evangelise pastors and through them bring the whole church to Shincheonji," he said.

Matthew said at the time he left, there were 10 to 15 pastors who were in ongoing conversations with Shincheonji and about five who were "eager to join".

Lee Man-hee founded Shincheonji in South Korea in 1984. (ABC News: Coco Veldkamp)

He said at least three Australian pastors were flown to South Korea for Shincheonji's graduation ceremony.

"It's a very, very slow process, and we have been in contact with them for years," Matthew said.

"We started off by emailing them or the church … we would cold call them and try to set up meetings.

"Slowly, we change their minds on certain topics, and that just builds up into accepting the Shincheonji doctrine."

Matthew said the Pastor Evangelism Team was operating under the name Zion Christian Mission Centre, so pastors did not immediately recognise it as Shincheonji.

Shincheonji's Australian Charities and Not-for-profits Commission page confirms it is affiliated with the Zion Christian Mission Centre.

Former Shincheonji members say people with religious backgrounds are targeted for recruitment. (ABC News: Coco Veldkamp)

He said the team explained Shincheonji in a positive way if pastors identified them and raised concerns about widely reported allegations of psychological abuse against the church.

"We sort of twist a lot of words … it wasn't really great what I did," Matthew said.

"We told pastors, 'You shouldn't believe what is online, but come listen to us.'"

The ABC has made numerous attempts to contact Shincheonji, but has not received a response.

Do you know more? Contact Coco Veldkamp on email cocoveldkamp@proton.me.

Recruitment records show outreach

The group's leader and founder is 94-year-old Lee Man-hee, a self-proclaimed Messiah, who claims to work together with the spirit of Jesus.

He has previously been found guilty of embezzling 5.6 billion won ($5.5 million), which was partly used to build a luxury "palace of peace" in Seoul.

Shincheonji has been accused of brainwashing its recruits, turning them against their families and friends, and manipulating them to devote their entire lives to the church and recruit new members, even to the point of sleep deprivation.

Shincheonji's South Korean website states that as of June 5th, 2024, the organisation had signed memorandums of understanding "with 12,538 churches in 83 countries".

"Additionally, 1,341 churches in 41 countries have joined Shincheonji Church of Jesus and replaced their signage," the statement said.

Shincheonji members rallying in front of Gyeonggi Provincial Office in 2024. (Supplied: Shincheonji)

A spreadsheet dated from early 2025 and leaked to the ABC shows Shincheonji tracking its attempts to convert 1,157 churches around the country.

In the spreadsheet, the targeted church, its denomination, pastor, contact details, and opening times are all listed.

The stage of communication with each church is also described, along with information obtained on pastors, including whether they are "poisoned" against the group.

The Church of Scientology of Melbourne, among a handful of others, is marked in the document as "unproceedable (cult)".

Another is marked "unproceedable due to belief in reincarnation", while many are marked "poisoned" or "poisoned hard", indicating that they believed Shincheonji was a cult or that they were opposed to Shincheonji.

However, the spreadsheet indicates a large number of pastors agreed to meet for coffee or invited them to their church.

Members of Shincheonji pay a tithe of 10 per cent of their earnings to the church, and are also pressured to make further donations regularly.

Reverend Frank Rasenberger says other church leaders had warned him about Shincheonji. (ABC News: Coco Veldkamp)

Recruiting large pre-existing congregations would dramatically boost the organisation's earnings, some of which go back to its headquarters in South Korea.

Matthew said the Pastor Evangelism Team attempted to discuss the bible and teach Shincheonji's interpretation during meetings to slowly indoctrinate pastors.

The ABC has also seen a chat group where members of the Pastor Evangelism Team post their progress with pastors in these lessons, including details gathered about the pastor's personal life and screenshots from Zoom meetings.

"We did get some results, mostly through non-denominational pastors … they don't really have people overseeing what they do," Matthew said.

Reverend rejects recruitment

The spreadsheet includes details from a phone call with a pastor at a St Albans church, who told the recruiter "you are in a cult and to get out".

Reverend Frank Rasenberger was the pastor of that church at that time.

Reverend Frank Rasenberger says Shincheonji recruiters approached him on multiple occasions. (ABC News: Coco Veldkamp)

"I was contacted several times … at least three times, I'd say, in various ways," Reverend Rasenberger said.

"One was an invitation to a big ecumenical event … under the guise of, 'this is going to be a great way for churches to come together'.

" But when I looked into it, I could see what it was. "

He said the recruiters were relentless.

"I turned that down … it didn't seem to stop them from contacting me," he said.

Reverend Rasenberger said he also had young people, inside and outside his church, confide to him that Shincheonji was pursuing them.

A Victorian parliamentary report on cults and fringe groups is due to be tabled in September 2026. (ABC News: Coco Veldkamp)

'Letter of oath'

The ABC has obtained a "letter of oath" signed by a pastor at a church in Western Australia.

The document includes a "pledge to God and Zion Christian Mission Centre".

A 'Pledge to God and Zion Christian Mission Centre' obtained by the ABC. (ABC News: Coco Veldkamp)

"I will obey and adhere to the order and instruction given by Zion Christian Mission Centre," it reads.

" If the terms and conditions are not followed, I will accept any consequential actions taken by the Zion Christian Mission Centre. "

In the "terms and conditions" section, members are sworn to secrecy.

"I will never leak the contents obtained by attending Zion Christian Mission Centre," it reads.

"I will never use the materials and lectures of Zion Christian Mission Centre for any other purpose than for studying at the Zion Christian Mission Centre."

'Abusive faith'

Tore Klevjir spent 11 years in Children of God, a Christian cult founded in the United States.

Tore Klevjer with two other disciples during his time in a Christian cult. (Supplied: Tore Klevjer)

Now, he is part of Cult Information and Family Support (CIFS), which offers help to cult survivors and their loved ones.

He said Shincheonji was the most prolific group CIFS dealt with.

"A rough estimate would be 50 to 60 inquiries over the last year from different families, ex-members and a couple from current members," Mr Klevjir said.

"It's by far the most influential group … they are very focused on recruiting, which is why they are really on our radar".

A Shincheonji bible seminar in Gwangju, South Korea, in 2025. (Supplied: Shincheonji)

Shincheonji claims to have churches in more than 100 countries and a congregation of more than 300,000 members, however some ex-members have told the ABC those numbers are inflated.

Shincheonji's Melbourne chapter is a registered charity on the Australian Charities and Not-for-profit Commission and is a recognised religious group, allowing it special legal protections and tax advantages.

Mr Klevjir said there needed to be stricter criteria for what can be considered a religion.

title: Consumers warned online retailers are relisting unsafe products
text:
A baby beach tent that posed a drowning hazard and a car stand that could not support its advertised weight were among the nearly 3,000 unsafe products recently removed by online retailers.

But some businesses resumed selling the potentially fatal products, or took too long to remove them from their websites, according to a report from the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC).

Consumer watchdog Choice said the report reveals "product safety washing" could be taking place in Australia's $60 billion online retail market.

A baby beach tent that posed a drowning hazard was recalled by the ACCC in January 2025. (Supplied: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission)

While some of Australia's largest retail platforms have signed up to a voluntary federal government "safety pledge", Choice campaign director Andy Kelly says it could instead be putting shoppers at risk.

Mr Kelly said safety washing happened when platforms gave the impression of upholding high safety standards without taking any meaningful action to keep consumers safe.

"The majority of Australians don't even really know that this is a problem," Mr Kelly said.

Australian Product Safety Pledge

Amazon Australia, eBay Australia and Chinese retailer AliExpress are the current signatories to the pledge run by the ACCC, with Catch and myDeal leaving the scheme when they shut down in 2025.

Temu's big Aussie ad spend infuriates mum of 9yo burnt in jumper fire Experts say Temu's strategy is causing a deluge of unsafe products to flood directly into Australian households.

However, last year's Australian Product Safety Pledge annual report, which did not name operational retailers, said one business resumed selling unsafe products after they had been taken down.

In another case, it said a platform removed unsafe products within the required two-day timeframe in only 69 per cent of cases.

An ACCC spokesperson said the regulator was working with signatories to introduce more stringent requirements.

The Australian Product Safety Pledge is a voluntary initiative established by the ACCC in 2020. (ABC News: John Gunn)

Spokespeople for Amazon Australia and eBay Australia said the companies had a strong commitment to product safety and used automated technology and human investigators to proactively detect and remove unsafe products.

Alibaba, the owner of AliExpress, did not respond to requests for comment.

'Product safety washing'

Choice has been calling for Australia to prohibit the sale of unsafe goods in line with the European Union, Canada and the US since 2020.

Currently, Australian laws are reactive and fines are given to companies found to have breached safety standards, with 18 companies fined since 2016.

It comes as a survey in 2024 found that most people mistakenly believe businesses are legally required to ensure products are safe.

Some of Australia's largest retail platforms have signed up to a voluntary federal government "safety pledge". (ABC News: Yasmine Wright Gittins)

"There's a risk that certain businesses use [the pledge] to engage in product safety washing without actually taking meaningful action," Mr Kelly said.

He said the "disappointing" performance of some signatories showed the need for reform of Australian consumer law to prohibit the sale of unsafe goods.

He said online operators needed to take meaningful action on safety and not use the ACCC pledge as a "marketing badge while falling short in practice".

Temu applies to join

One omission from the pledge is Temu, which has emerged as Australia's biggest online retailer.

The Chinese business said it would join the pledge in March 2024 after an eight-year-old girl was badly burnt while wearing a hoodie purchased from its platform.

Daniella Jacobs-Herd sustained burns to 13 per cent of her body while wearing a hoodie her grandmother bought from Temu. (Supplied: Hannah Jacobs-Herd)

But last month, the company and the ACCC said its application was still in process.

The girl's mother, Hannah Jacobs-Herd, said she felt Temu's commitment to join the pledge was an example of the "product safety washing" referred to by Mr Kelly.

"I feel that it's just words they said to try and prolong the process and hoping this would all just be swept under the rug," she said.

Shine lawyers say Temu has deferred liability for the recalled hoodie to its Chinese supplier. (Reuters: Dado Ruvic/Illustration)

Ms Jacobs-Herd launched a lawsuit against Temu, which she said had stalled because the platform deferred liability for the hoodie to its Chinese supplier.

Temu has banned that seller from selling children's products on its platform.

A spokesperson for Shine Lawyers, the law firm handling the lawsuit, said attempts to contact the supplier directly had been unsuccessful.

title: Matildas star Mary Fowler returns from injury ahead of Asian Cup
text:
Matildas star Mary Fowler has made her return to action in the Women's Super League, on a day of huge celebration for Manchester City.

After nine-and-a-half months on the sidelines with an anterior cruciate ligament injury she suffered in last season's Women's FA Cup semifinal, Fowler came on as a substitute in the 75th minute of City's fabulous 5-1 victory over champions Chelsea at the Etihad Stadium on Sunday.

She was left beaming as she made her return with her side coasting at 5-1. City's two superstars Vivianne Miedema and Khadija Shaw, who'd both scored earlier in the game, both embraced with the 22-year-old on the touchline as they were replaced in the 76th minute.

The home crowd also rose as one to celebrate on what proved a landmark day, with City handing the ailing champions one of their worst ever WSL defeats. It felt like a changing-of-the-guard moment, with Chelsea now looking sure to be dethroned after six successive titles.

Fowler, inevitably, had to shake off some rustiness during her cameo but slotted in to her centre forward role comfortably enough as City eased to a win that puts them 11 points clear of neighbours Manchester United and 12 clear of Chelsea.

South Korea boycott would be 'devastating' for Asian Cup Asian Cup organisers say they are hopeful the South Korean women's team will partake in next month's tournament despite threats of a boycott.

The visitors brought Fowler's Matildas captain Sam Kerr on early in the second half, but she proved largely ineffective with Chelsea already 3-0 down and being outclassed.

Their only consolation came from an Alyssa Thompson strike when they were 4-0 down.

The great news for Australia's Women's Asian Cup hopes is that both their key attacking threats should now be back in harness for the home tournament that begins on March 1 with a fixture against Philippines in Perth.

AAP

title: Live: ASX down as gold miners tumble on precious metals rout
text:
One of the enduring mysteries of last year was: what's going on at Housing Australia?

The inadvertent leak of the incoming government brief for Treasurer Jim Chalmers and Housing Minster Clare O'Neil laid out lots of challenges for the pair.

The advice suggested taxes needed to be raised, spending cut and that the government's key election promise - to build 1.2 million homes over five years - "would not be met".

Buried in the brief, it identified "challenges" with the "responsiveness … capability … [and] speed" of key housing agency Housing Australia and suggested "steps to improve oversight and reset the relationship with the CEO and board" of the body.

What did that mean?

The departure of the Housing Australia chair Carol Austin in October might have been part of that picture.

Today the Financial Review's Michael Bleby has more.

A secret review commissioned by the government found it had a "high risk approach" and the chair would attend meetings held by an independent audit committee.

The Fin reports the review by consulting firm Deloitte was handed to the agency's board and found the organisation had not developed “an overarching, or individual program plan(s)” for its key funding schemes, despite those programs having already been open to proposals for six months.

Additionally, as Austin had attended meetings of the board’s independent audit and risk committee, there was “a risk that the ARC meetings may not be operating with a sufficient level of independence from the board”.

The paper attempted to contact Ms Austin but was unsuccessful.

At the time of the leak of the Treasury papers, both the Treasurer and Housing Minister reiterated the 1.2 million figure was "ambitious".

In a recent media release, Ms O'Neil called the target aspirational, while noting that ABS data on new home starts was at its highest level in three years.

“These are encouraging figures that show that the reforms federal Labor is leading with our state and territory government partners, are starting to bear fruit," she said in a statement in January.

title: A peek inside the long-overdue Glasshouse theatre
text:
Advertisement

NationalQueenslandPerforming arts A peek inside the long-overdue Glasshouse theatre Julius Dennis February 2, 2026 — 1:45pm Save You have reached your maximum number of saved items. Remove items from your saved list to add more. Save this article for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime. Got it Share A A A

Brisbane’s long-awaited new performing arts centre has opened its doors for the first time, revealing a sleek and high-tech arena designed to slip into the existing precinct. Behind the giant curved-class exterior on the second level, golden carpets lead to long, black bars where theatre-goers will order drinks in little plastic cups. Inside, 1500 “rainforest green” seats stretch in front of a wide stage. The room feels intimate despite the scale of the building, which required more than 6300 cubic metres of concrete and 1500 tonnes of steel, along with all that glass. The visually stunning building was four years behind schedule. David Kelly On the stage, automated fly lines and sound shells hover at the ready, replacing hand-run systems at QPAC’s older theatres. Backstage, 79 mirror spaces mean the theatre can easily accommodate larger performances.

Advertisement

According to architect Jayson Blight, who gave a tour to media on Monday, the mission of the building was to blend into the existing centre, not cast a shadow over it. He also said the complex structure of the 217 undulating panes meant they supported themselves. On stage at The Glasshouse. Julius Dennis “There is actually no structure holding up that glass,” he told the crowd, some of whom laughing nervously. Named The Glasshouse after a public survey to choose a moniker, the theatre was meant to open its doors in 2022, but flooding and COVID-19 pushed it back four years.

Advertisement

Still, Arts Minister John-Paul Langbroek said there was no cost blowout to match, thanks to a $184 million guaranteed construction sum contract with the builder, Lendlease. The Queensland Performing Arts Centre contributed $25 million, with the rest provided by the state, he said. The level foyer behind the bending glass. Julius Dennis “It certainly has taken a long time, but it’s really important to acknowledge that we’re here now, and it’s a wonderful theatre,” Langbroek said. Public Works Minister Sam O’Connor described the issues faced during the project as biblical.

Advertisement

“We had the floods here in 2022; we had the COVID pandemic prior to that,” he said, as well as laying blame at how “the former Labor government handled the CFMEU”, who had a strong presence on the site throughout the project. Despite that dig, both ministers thanked the more than 2500 workers who brought the theatre to life. “They should all be proud of their efforts to produce what is truly one of the most beautiful buildings in our state,” O’Connor said. QPAC chief executive Rachel Healy said the new 1500-seat theatre — to go along with the 2000-seat Lyric — would attract an extra 300,000 visitors to the arts precinct annually. “The opening of the Glasshouse Theatre will also see us build on our reputation as one of Australia’s most dynamic and popular cultural destinations,” she said.

Advertisement

Among the first shows to be performed at The Glasshouse is the April opening of musical The Last Ship, written and performed by Sting, the story of a British community losing their shipyard. The theatre will officially open to the public on March 3. Get alerts on significant breaking news as happens. Sign up for our Breaking News Alert.

title: Grammys 2026: Full list of winners and nominees
text:
Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime.

Remove items from your saved list to add more.

You have reached your maximum number of saved items.

Trevor Noah’s opening monologue had not even started when Australia’s own Tame Impala, aka Kevin Parker, took home a golden gramophone at the 68th Annual Grammy Awards.

End of Summer’s victory in the best dance/electronic recording category was awarded during the pre-telecast Grammys ceremony, and is Parker’s second consecutive Grammy win after his victory in the same category last year for Neverender.

Justin Bieber, Amyl and The Sniffers and Ye will all be part of the 2026 Grammy Awards on Monday, broadcasting live from 12pm AEDT. Sydney Morning Herald

Meanwhile, Melbourne pub rock band Amyl and the Sniffers – who won album of the year during a total domination of the 2025 ARIA Awards – were nominated for best rock performance thanks to U Should Not Be Doing That but lost out to the late Ozzy Osbourne’s protege, Yungblud.

Sydney’s Rufus Du Sol’s album Inhale/Exhale also lost out in the best dance/electronic album category, while FKA Twigs emerged victorious with Eusexua.

title: Grammys 2026 LIVE updates: Justin Bieber performs in silk boxers and socks after four-year hiatus
text:
Melbourne’s own Rosé and Bruno Mars, in rock-star mode, open the show with a particularly Blues Brothers-ish take on their smash APT (I guess Bruno is the Belushi?). At least Billie Eilish is bouncing around in the front row.

Rosé, left, and Bruno Mars perform APT. Chris Pizzello/Invision/AP

Comedian Trevor Noah, somehow back to host his sixth consecutive (and, he promises, final) Grammys, gets the ceremony going with a gag comparing APT, the Korean drinking game, with its US equivalent. “Every time we turn on the news, we take a drink,” he jokes.

He takes a walk through the audience, shouting out stars including Pharrell and Tyler, The Creator. “I feel like I’m at Jeff Bezos’ wedding, but with way more black people,” he says.

Loading

Justin Bieber, at his first Grammys since 2022, looks nervous when Noah heads his way. But he keeps the jokes mild, congratulating Bieber and partner Hailey on their child and requesting a discount voucher for her make-up line Rhode.

His monologue is political-lite. He shouts out Olivia Dean for fighting Ticketmaster’s ticket prizes, and calls Doechii’s Anxiety the US’ new national anthem.

He even gets an applause when he announces that Nicki Minaj, who’s been recently red-pilled, isn’t at the show. “She is still at the White House with Donald Trump,” he says, doing an impression of them comparing their arse sizes. I feel Trump would love that one.

title: Trevor Noah roasts celebrities at the Grammys
text:
Trevor Noah roasts celebrities at the Grammys

Trevor Noah did not hold back as host of the Grammys with his opening monologue poking fun at Jeff Bezos, the Beibers and Nicky Minaj.
